channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: E.U. Offers Billions in Aid to Ukraine as Kerry and Lavrov Meet in Paris
item.description: With Russia’s grip on Crimea providing a backdrop to talks in Paris on Wednesday, a European aid package of as much as $15 billion offered financial underpinning to a struggling Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Letter from India: Old Fantasies Are Distorted in Indian Elections
item.description: The Indian elections are largely about the rise of the fierce Hindu nationalist Narendra Modi and the political responses to his ascent.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Karzai’s Brother Is Expected to Drop Out of Afghanistan’s Presidential Race
item.description: Reports of Qayum Karzai’s expected withdrawal follow what officials have described as months of behind-the-scenes pressure from President Hamid Karzai.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai has pressured his brother Qayum Karzai, shown above, to withdraw from the presidential election for months, officials said.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 5
item.description: Former Australian cricketer Brett Lee with the ICC Cricket World Cup 2015 trophy in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Brett Lee, a former Australian cricketer, during an event in New Delhi to unveil the ICC Cricket World Cup 2015 trophy.

item.title: Lens Blog: Carnival’s Essence in Black and White
item.description: Stripping away the usual hot colors of the Caribbean, Pablo Delano has captured Trinidad’s Carnival culture at its essence.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW BORYGA

item.title: Israel Says It Seized Iranian Shipment of Rockets Headed for Gaza
item.description: Israeli commandos boarded the ship in international waters as it headed to Port Sudan.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Close Ties to Russia, China Sets a Cautious Tone on Ukraine Crisis
item.description: China has joined international voices calling for peace and stability in Ukraine, while continuing to withhold criticism of Russia, its traditional partner.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Bits Blog: Cyberattacks Rise as Ukraine Crisis Spills to Internet
item.description: Security experts say that they are currently witnessing unusually large denial-of-service attacks directed at both pro-Western and pro-Russian Ukrainian news sites.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Opposing Narratives in Piecing Together Kunming Attackers’ Motives
item.description: Were the assailants who slashed to death 29 people and wounded 143 others at a train station in China last Saturday aspiring jihadists or would-be refugees seeking to flee the country?
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: A doctor checking a patient who was wounded in the stabbing attack at the Kunming train station in China on Saturday.

item.title: India Ink: India’s 814 Million Voters Get Their Polling Dates
item.description: Over nine election days in April and May, Indians will choose their representatives for the Lok Sabha, the lower house or Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: A woman casting her vote inside a polling booth in the old part of Delhi during the state assembly elections on Dec. 4.

item.title: Israel Fires on Militants Along Syrian Border
item.description: The events were the latest sign of how spillover from the Syrian civil war threatens to destabilize a long-quiet cease-fire line.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Surabaya Journal: Pointing Fingers Over Heavy Death Toll at an Indonesian Zoo
item.description: The municipal zoo in Surabaya, Indonesia’s second-largest city, where more than 100 animals have died since last summer, has drawn calls for its closing.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pelicans during a show at the municipal zoo in Surabaya, Indonesia, where more than 100 animals have died since last summer. Critics around the world have called for the zoo to be closed.

item.title: Arundhati Roy, the Not-So-Reluctant Renegade
item.description: The writer has turned again to fiction. But will her politics get in the way?
item.dc:creator: By SIDDHARTHA DEB
item.media:credit: Chiara Goia for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roy, at home in New Delhi.

item.title: India Sets Dates for Nationwide Elections
item.description: The world’s largest vote, set to begin April 7, will see as many as 814 million people select a Parliament to elect a leader in India’s most consequential race in decades.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Stealth Changes for China’s Stealth Fighter
item.description: The maker of the J-20 stealth fighter, Chengdu Aerospace Corporation, appears to be upgrading the aircraft as it tests it, based on photos circulating this week.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY DOYLE
item.media:description: The Chinese J-20 stealth fighter, in Chengdu, Sichuan Province, in 2011.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Declares ‘War Against Pollution’
item.description: Facing growing dissatisfaction from citizens about high pollution in China, the premier, Li Keqiang, declared in his work report Wednesday that the government he leads would “declare war” on pollution.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A group of Chinese and foreigners distributed face masks to pedestrians on the Bund in Shanghai in January to raise awareness of air pollution.

item.title: India Ink: Bangalore Welcomes a Later Last Call
item.description: The young professionals of the city say it’s about time that the government allowed bars and restaurants to close at 1 a.m., instead of 11:30 p.m.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
item.media:credit: Namas Bhojani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hanging out in a pub in Bangalore, India, in 2004. The city's bars and restaurants will extend operations until 1 a.m. for a three-month trial run.

item.title: U.S. Takes Training Role in Africa as Threats Grow and Budgets Shrink
item.description: The American military’s involvement in Niger illustrates how the Pentagon is trying to juggle two competing missions in Africa: contain the spread of Islamist militancy without having to pour a lot of soldiers or money into the region.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Senegalese commandos approach the village of Marke, Niger, as part of American-supervised training exercises for the forces of several African nations.

item.title: China Announces 12.2% Increase in Military Budget
item.description: China announced that it was increasing its military budget for 2014 to almost $132 billion. The expansion is being closely watched by other nations in the region and by the United States.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Mexico Targets Gang That Infiltrated the Mining Industry
item.description: The smuggling of lucrative iron ore is an example of the way Mexican organized crime groups have expanded beyond drug trafficking into a diverse range of rackets.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Netanyahu Promotes Efforts Toward a Peace Deal
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel suggested that he had listened to President Obama’s plea to sign on to a framework being drafted by Secretary of State John Kerry.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel addressing the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, on Tuesday. He offered an upbeat message.

item.title: Chinese Officials Seek to Shift Attention From Rampage
item.description: Days after knife-wielding assailants killed 29 people and injured 143 at the train station in Kunming, Chinese authorities appeared eager to change the subject.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: A woman grieved on Saturday for her husband, one of 29 people killed by knife-wielding assailants at a train station.

item.title: A New Magazine for Fans of the Vatican’s Biggest Star
item.description: A testament to Pope Francis’ continuing popularity, Il Mio Papa (My Pope) will offer a glossy medley of papal pronouncements and photographs, and peeks into his personal life.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: An Italian publisher of celebrity gossip promises respectful coverage, and a poster, in the weekly Il Mio Papa (My Pope). The main headline shown is “Have the Courage to Be Happy.”

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Putin Really Wants
item.description: Russia’s goal isn’t annexation of Crimea. It wants to keep a thorn in the side of Ukraine’s new government.
item.dc:creator: By RUSLAN PUKHOV

item.title: No Bloodshed in a Standoff at an Airfield in Ukraine
item.description: After a standoff, heavily armed Russians allowed several members of an unarmed Ukrainian Air Force unit in Belbek to return to their usual posts.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK REEVELL
